overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [14] This program allocates funds to the counties for the purchase of equity in an accessory dwelling unit by the State and specifies eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non‑reoccurring closing costs. [14] [14] The Act sunsets on January 1, 2031, and appropriates moneys for infrastructure projects. [14]
appropriations: This measure has been amended by appropriating an unspecified amount, for fiscal year 2025-2026, into and out of the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund, to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the purposes of infrastructure projects. [15] Your Committee recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. [15] For the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program, the corporation shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) per year. [14]
assumptions_and_methodology: HHFDC testimony notes that the ceiling of $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) per year will limit the reach of the program. [13] Assuming that the average value of participating properties is $1,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), the cost of the deed restriction is $80,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and $40,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) of equity is provided for each ADU, the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year. [13] The Department of Taxation estimates a revenue loss based on the conveyance tax exemption. [13]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the corporation an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program. [14] The corporation may allocate funds from the rental housing revolving fund to a county and may adopt rules pursuant to chapter 91 for the purposes of this subpart. [14] [14] Counties shall be responsible for validating the evidence and ensuring compliance with this subpart and may contract with non-government persons or entities to ensure compliance. [14] The Department of Taxation can administer the tax law changes in section 6 of the bill with the January 1, 2026, effective date. [13]
economic_impact: Increasing the supply of accessory dwelling units is an important strategy to help address the shortage of rental housing units in Hawaii. [15] The deed restriction program will create an inventory of homes for local residents, stabilize home prices, and reduce speculation in our housing market. [13] The Department of Taxation estimates a revenue loss to the General Fund from FY 2026 through FY 2031 due to the conveyance tax exemption. [13]
policy_impact: This Act establishes the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program by adding a new subpart to chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [14] The Act amends section 247-3, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to exempt any document or instrument conveying real property with a county-owned deed restriction from the conveyance tax. [14] A deed restriction shall be recorded against the property and shall run with the land in perpetuity, binding all future owners, successors, and assigns. [14]
revenue_sources: The accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program is funded through the allocation of funds from the rental housing revolving fund. [14] The Act also appropriates an amount out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii to be deposited into the dwelling unit revolving fund for infrastructure projects. [14] [14] If a property with a deed restriction is sold to a nonresident, the corporation shall be entitled to fifty per cent of appreciation at the time of sale, to be collected by the corporation and placed in the rental housing revolving fund. [14] [14]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This Act shall be repealed on January 1, 2031. [14] For the accessory dwelling unit program, the corporation shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) per year. [14] The Department of Taxation estimates a general fund revenue loss from the conveyance tax exemption as follows: -0.9 million in FY 2026, -1.9 million in FY 2027, -2.0 million in FY 2028, -2.1 million in FY 2029, -2.2 million in FY 2030, and -2.3 million in FY 2031. [13] There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the dwelling unit revolving fund, from which an unspecified sum is appropriated for infrastructure projects. [14] [14] [14] The Committee on Ways and Means recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund for this purpose. [15] A homeowner participating in the purchase of equity shall repay the corporation its prorated share of the appraised value of the completed accessory dwelling unit, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale or transfer of the property, whichever occurs first. [14] [14] If a county does not expend moneys allocated pursuant to this section within one year of receipt, the moneys shall be returned to the corporation. [14] This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2050, provided that section 6, which creates the conveyance tax exemption, shall take effect on January 1, 2026. [14] [14]
operating_revenue_impact: The Department of Taxation estimates a general fund revenue loss from the conveyance tax exemption starting in FY 2026. [13] If a property with a deed restriction in place is sold to a nonresident, the corporation is entitled to fifty per cent of appreciation at the time of sale, which is to be collected and placed in the rental housing revolving fund. [14] [14] A homeowner participating in the purchase of equity program shall repay the corporation its prorated share of the appraised value of the completed accessory dwelling unit, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale or transfer of the property, whichever occurs first. [14] [14]
capital_expenditure_impact: There is appropriated out of the dwelling unit revolving fund an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2025-2026 for infrastructure projects. [14] The Committee on Ways and Means recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) for this purpose. [15] Under the accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program, the corporation may allocate funds to a county to finance construction costs, development costs, and non‑reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of accessory dwelling units. [14]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: This Act shall be repealed on January 1, 2031. [14] A deed restriction shall be recorded against the property and shall run with the land in perpetuity, binding all future owners, successors, and assigns. [14] Counties shall be responsible for validating the evidence and ensuring compliance with this subpart on an ongoing basis. [14]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: While the previous version of the bill funded the ADU program from the Rental Housing Revolving Fund, this version adds a new appropriation for infrastructure projects. [15] The measure now appropriates an unspecified amount from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the dwelling unit revolving fund. [14] [14] A subsequent appropriation is made from the dwelling unit revolving fund for infrastructure projects, for which the committee recommends an amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt).
